ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

McLane Southern California is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities.  This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility.  For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration system.  Only trained operators are permitted to perform system operations.  McLane Southern California has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition.  All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility.  In addition, these programs incorporate emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur.  At such an event, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

McLane Southern California is located at 4472 Georgia Boulevard in San Bernardino, California.  Ammonia is used in the facility's refrigeration system to provide cooling for cold storage warehousing.  The system uses a maximum of 20,800 pounds of ammonia to provide refrigeration for the Dock, Cooler, and Freezer. The majority of the system is located in the engine room including vessels and compressors. The condensers are mounted on the roof, and all of the evaporators are located in their respective cold areas.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

McLane Southern California has developed an accidental release prevention program for compliance with the OES CalARP regulations.  The program includes but is not limited to the following elements:



?    Safety information regarding the chemical hazards, and operating and technical specifications for the equipment;

?    Written procedures for operating and maintaining the processes;

?    Training for employees involved with system

EAP.  In the event of an ammonia release, employees will evacuate or shelter-in-place, depending on the nature of the release, and the facility will contact the refrigeration contractor and fire department for assistance as necessary.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Process Hazard Analysis', Compliance Audits, and Seismic Assessments have been performed on the ammonia refrigeration system, and these studies have resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility.  The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment.  McLane Southern California has implemented several of these action items and is moving forward with completing the remaining outstanding recommendations.   In addition, the facility plans to continue providing employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.
